page.title: 17Local History of Beeley Moor
page.content: The houses in the Hipper valley are old, Harewood Grange being noted in 1486 and was formerly owned by Beauchief Abbey, when it was used by the monks as a penitentiary. A similarly old house: Peasunhurst is thought to have existed about 1645 and to have Quaker associations. A fairly prominant feature of the area is the old road which ran from Hardwick Hall to Chatsworth House and reputed to be one along which Bess of Hardwick travelled. This is marked by circles of stone, now containing deciduous trees but originally built as shelters and markers for travellers during inclement weather. The most recent disturbance of the moor was in 1964 when the North Sea Gas pipeline cut across the land and is marked at intervals with posts topped by luminous red triangles.
